docs.snippet: The United States is “half-asleep at the wheel,” while Europe has new regulations soon to take effect, a reader says.

headline.main: Look to Europe for Guidance on Data Privacy

docs.snippet: Influence and authority come in so many forms that we could argue forever about who really holds them. But there are at least some clear winners.

headline.main: Everyone Wants ‘Power.’ Everyone Thinks Someone Else Has It.

docs.snippet: Getting companies to pay for the information they reap from people’s online lives will improve the data and may counteract a concentration of power.

headline.print_headline: Getting Tech Giants to Pay You for Your Data
headline.main: Your Data Is Crucial to a Robotic Age. Shouldn’t You Be Paid for It?

docs.snippet: The company harvested data from 50 million Facebook users to develop psychological profiles on behalf of political campaigns, including that of President Trump.

headline.print_headline: Investigators Raid Office  Of Data Firm In London
headline.main: British Authorities Search Offices of Cambridge Analytica

docs.snippet: In his first public statements concerning a scandal involving Cambridge Analytica, Mark Zuckerberg said “there’s more to do, and we need to step up and do it.”

headline.print_headline: Facebook’s Chief Admits Mistakes In Guarding Data
headline.main: Zuckerberg, Facing Facebook’s Worst Crisis Yet, Pledges Better Privacy

docs.snippet: It’s true that the Cambridge Analytica incident wasn’t a security breach. It was something far worse.
Mark Zuckerberg said Facebook’s reliance on advertising aligned with its mission to build a community. But what if Facebook cost $5 per month to use?

headline.main: Kevin’s Week in Tech: Zuckerberg’s Answers to Privacy Scandal Raise More Questions

docs.snippet: Amid a data scandal this week, Mr. Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, and Sheryl Sandberg, chief operating officer, have been nowhere to be found in public.

headline.main: Missing From Facebook’s Crisis: Mark Zuckerberg

docs.snippet: Readers discuss how Cambridge Analytica provided information to the Trump campaign.
How did the brains behind Cambridge Analytica, the political research firm that worked with the Trump campaign, become its whistle-blower?

headline.main: Listen to ‘The Daily’: The Data Harvesters
